MEDICATIONS: Not specified in transcript.

ALLERGIES: Not specified in transcript.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
General: Reports difficulty remembering to take blood pressure medication.
Eyes: Reports sudden visual distortions, blurring, crooked lines, and difficulty adjusting to dim lights.
Cardiovascular: Reports difficulty remembering to take blood pressure medication.
Respiratory: Reports smoking one pack of cigarettes per day.

O:
VITAL SIGNS: Not specified in transcript.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
Eyes:
Anterior segment examination reveals posterior chamber intraocular lenses (PCIOLs) in both eyes.
Right eye: Cornea is clear. No neovascularization of the iris (MVI). PCIOL present. Cup to disc ratio is 0.2. Fundus examination shows the retina is attached 360 degrees without any tears or holes. Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes are noted in the fovea. Posterior segment exam shows drusen in the macula, thickening of the retina, presence of subretinal fluid, exudates accumulation, and positive for hemorrhage.
Left eye: Cornea is clear. No MVI. Cup to disc ratio is 0.3. RPE changes are noted in the fovea. No hemorrhage or subretinal fluid. Retina is attached.

DIAGNOSTIC RESULTS:
Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Shows drusen deposit and retinal pigment epithelium with subretinal fluid accumulation. Choroidal neovascular membrane is visualized.
Fluorescein Angiography (FA): Reveals focal areas of leakage in the right eye, consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration.

A:
1. Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration (Wet AMD), Right Eye: Based on subjective report of sudden visual distortions, blurring, crooked lines, and difficulty with dim lights, correlated with objective findings on eye examination (drusen, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, exudates, hemorrhage in the macula of the right eye) and diagnostic testing (OCT showing subretinal fluid and neovascular membrane, FA showing focal leakage in the right eye). This is indicative of advanced neovascular AMD, which occurs when abnormal blood vessels grow beneath the retina and leak fluid and blood, leading to severe vision loss.

P:
1. Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration (Wet AMD), Right Eye:
    - Medical Treatment: Proceed with Lucentis injection into the vitreous portion of the right eye. The eye will be numbed prior to injection.
    - Frequency: Injections will be given once a month.
    - Patient Education: Discussed the nature of neovascular AMD (wet AMD), explaining that abnormal blood vessels are growing and leaking fluid/blood, which causes the symptoms and can lead to a large blind spot and severe vision loss. Explained the rationale for Lucentis injections, the procedure details (intravitreous injection after numbing), and potential outcomes (may slow vision decline or stop further loss, but disease and vision loss may still progress despite treatment).
    - Patient Agreement: Patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan.
    - Follow-up: Continue with regular monthly injections over a period of time.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right ankle injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Jacqueline Price is a pleasant 28-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right ankle injury. The patient sustained the injury when she fell while in mountain biking lessons. She states that her ankle twisted outward. The patient localizes the pain to her lateral aspect of her right ankle. She denies any tingling, but notes numbness in her toes. She notes that she is able to move her ankle a little bit. The patient states that she has difficulty walking. Additionally, she notes that she has a limp when she ambulates. She has taken Tylenol for the pain, but states that it was not beneficial. She denies hearing a pop, but did hear a crack when the injury happened. Ms. Price notes that she has had a fever.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been mountain biking for 3 years.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right ankle pain.
Neurological: Reports numbness in the right ankle.

VITALS

Temperature in offce today was 98.6.
BP: 118/77.
HR: 77 bpm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Mild edema.
MSK: Examination of the right ankle there is edema and erythema on the lateral malleolus on the right side. There is associated ecchymosis and a few excoriations. Pain with palpation of the right lateral malleolus. Decreased flexion and extension of the right ankle, as well as internal and external rotation. There is no apparent injury to the right knee or foot.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right foot taken in office today reveals no acute fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Acute right ankle sprain.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's x-rays in detail today. The plan is to place the patient in an Aircast and provide the patient with crutches. I have also prescribed the patient meloxicam 15 mg to treat the pain. I have advised her to ice the area for 20 minutes 5 times per day. She can weight-bear as tolerated. I anticipate that she will improve in the next 2 weeks. If her pain does not improve with the Aircast, I will recommend formal physical therapy or pursuing further imaging.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports an myocardial infarction.

SURGICAL HISTORY

Patient reports stent placement in the right coronary artery.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient is a fan of the Denver Nuggets basketball team. He also enjoys swimming.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Brilinta twice a day every 12 hours, aspirin 81 mg at night, Crestor 40 mg once a day, and Toprol 50 mg once a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath with exertion.
Skin: Denies redness or infection in the right wrist.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 127/60.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention. No carotid bruits.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base. No gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Right radial artery cardiac catheterization site is clean, dry, and intact. No hematoma. Palpable radial pulse.

RESULTS

The ejection fraction, obtained while he was hospitalized, was measured at approximately 50%, which is in the low normal range.

I reviewed the patient’s recent echocardiogram which demonstrates mild mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Inferior myocardial infarction.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well. His catheterization site is healing well.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained the importance of continuing to take his medications to prevent the stent from clogging again and to reduce his chance of another heart attack. I encouraged him to limit his salt intake as an increased amount of sodium can affect the ejection fraction measurement of his heart function.
- Medical Treatment: The patient is taking a low-dose aspirin, and will continue taking it for life or until he is instructed to discontinue. Continue Brilinta for at least 1 year. Continue Crestor 40 mg once a day. Continue Toprol 50 mg once a day. The patient can resume swimming a few laps. He will enroll in cardiac rehab to gain confidence in returning to exercising and for dietary education and counseling. Liver function studies and lipid panel ordered. Repeat echocardiogram ordered to be performed in 6 months.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 6 weeks to review his studies.

note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly Howard is a pleasant 33-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain.

The patient reports that she fell off of a tandem bicycle and struck her right knee on a curb approximately 2 weeks ago. After the injury, she took ibuprofen and treated the wound, but the pain has persisted. She localizes her pain to the medial aspect of the knee. She also reports occasional clicking with full extension of the knee, as well as occasional instability with ambulation. The patient states that her pain is the worst when ambulating up an incline. She denies any previous right knee issues. She enjoys walking her dogs and swimming but has not done this since her injury.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient works in a Children's Hospital.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, clicking, and instability.

PHYSICAL EXAM

SKIN: Warm, dry and intact
MSK: 
Examination of the right knee: Tenderness along the medial joint line. Pes bursa is nontender. The epicondyle and posterior aspect of her knee are soft. Popliteal space is nontender. The lateral aspect of her knee is nontender. There is a dime-sized abrasion that is dry and appears to be 1 week old, over the medial patella. No scars. Full extension. Full symmetric flexion. No deformity. Valgus stress of the medial and lateral collateral ligament are intact. Laxity with posterior drawer testing. 1+ posterior drawer test. Negative Lachman test. Patella tracks fine. No crepitus. Negative McMurray test.
Examination of the left knee: Full symmetric flexion. No deformity. Valgus stress of the medial collateral ligament is intact. Lateral collateral ligament is intact.

RESULTS

4 views of the right knee were taken. These reveal no evidence of any fractures or dislocations. Joint space is well preserved. No other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Right knee pain, possible posterior cruciate ligament sprain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we had a lengthy discussion in regard to her current symptoms. I explained that her x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I recommend we obtain an MRI of the right knee to evaluate for a possible posterior cruciate ligament injury. In the meantime, I have recommended that the patient be placed in a brace to provide increased support. I have also recommended that the patient attend formal physical therapy to work on her range of motion and strengthening. I advised her to ice her right knee a few times a day to reduce the swelling. She can continue taking her ibuprofen if she finds this helpful, but I am also going to send in a prescription medication she can take less frequently. The patient will follow up with me in 4 to 6 weeks to check on her progress.

ORDERS

MRI, right knee
Prescription medication
augmented note:
S:
**Chief Complaint:** Right knee pain.

**History of Present Illness:** Beverly Howard is a 33-year-old female presenting for evaluation of right knee pain that began approximately two weeks ago after falling off a tandem bicycle and striking her right knee on a curb. She reports immediate soreness and took ibuprofen and treated a wound. The pain has persisted daily since the injury. She localizes the pain to the medial aspect of the knee. She reports occasional clicking with full extension and occasional instability with ambulation. Her pain is worst when walking up an incline. Ibuprofen helps temporarily, but the pain returns. She denies any prior issues with her right knee.

**Past Medical History:** Denies previous right knee issues.
**Past Surgical History:** Not discussed.
**Family History:** Not discussed.
**Social History:** Works as a baby rocker in a children's hospital. Enjoys walking her dog and swimming, but has not swum since the injury. Occasional swimmer. Does not play organized sports currently.

**Review of Systems:**
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, clicking, and instability.
*Other systems not discussed.*

**Medications:** Ibuprofen (dose/frequency not specified, patient took it).
**Allergies:** Not discussed.

O:
**Vitals:** Not documented.

**Physical Exam:**
Right Knee:
Skin: Dime-sized abrasion, dry, appears approximately one week old, located over the medial patella. No scars.
Musculoskeletal: Tenderness along the medial joint line. Pes bursa nontender. Epicondyle nontender. Popliteal space nontender. Posterior aspect soft, no pain reported. Lateral side nontender. Full extension with occasional clicking. Full symmetric flexion. No deformity. Valgus stress testing reveals medial collateral ligament intact. Lateral collateral ligament intact. Laxity noted with posterior drawer testing, estimated as 1+ posterior drawer. Anterior drawer negative. Lachman test negative. Patella tracks fine, no crepitus. McMurray test negative (medial and lateral).
Left Knee:
Musculoskeletal: Full symmetric flexion. No deformity. Valgus stress testing reveals medial collateral ligament intact. Lateral collateral ligament intact. Posterior drawer feels normal compared to the right.

**Imaging:**
Right Knee X-rays (4 views): Reviewed. Appear normal and healthy. Bone edges look good, no bone spurs or fractures seen. Kneecap tracking looks good. Joint space is preserved (cartilage visible). Both knees appear the same on X-ray. No obvious abnormalities noted.

A:
**Right knee pain** likely secondary to bicycle fall and impact injury.
Differential diagnoses include:
- **Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) sprain/injury:** Suspected based on mechanism of injury (impact causing tibia to shift posteriorly) and physical exam finding of 1+ posterior drawer laxity.
- Meniscus injury
- Chipped cartilage

X-rays rule out fracture or obvious bony abnormality. Clinical exam findings suggest possible ligamentous injury, specifically PCL, but internal derangement (meniscus, cartilage) cannot be ruled out without further imaging. Isolated PCL injuries often do not require surgery, but concurrent injuries might.

P:
**Right Knee Pain / Suspected PCL Injury:**
1.  **Imaging:** Obtain MRI of the right knee to further evaluate the posterior cruciate ligament, menisci, and articular cartilage to confirm diagnosis and assess for concurrent injuries.
2.  **Bracing:** Fit patient with a temporary brace today for support.
3.  **Physical Therapy:** Provide referral for formal physical therapy to work on range of motion and strengthening. Recommend starting with a couple visits, frequency to be determined based on patient progress and home exercise capabilities.
4.  **Pain/Swelling Management:**
    *   Apply ice packs to the right knee a few times per day.
    *   Continue ibuprofen up to three times per day if helpful.
    *   Prescribe an alternative prescription medication (twice daily dosing) to be called into the patient's pharmacy as an option for less frequent dosing. Patient can revert to ibuprofen if preferred.
5.  **Patient Education:** Discussed X-ray findings (no fracture). Explained suspicion of PCL injury and rationale for MRI. Discussed conservative treatment plan (brace, PT, pain control) and the possibility of surgery only if instability persists after several months of conservative management.
6.  **Follow-up:** Schedule follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks to recheck progress after starting treatment and reviewing MRI results.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left arm pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Zachary Wood is a 45-year-old right-hand-dominant male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left arm pain. The onset of his pain began yesterday when he woke up with pain. He denies any specific injury. The patient locates his pain from his left elbow up all the way to his neck. He describes his pain as an achiness. The patient has been taking Motrin for pain, which does not provide him with relief. He also reports intermittent chest pain that radiates up his neck. He notes that he had to stop cutting the grass the other day because of chest pain. The patient denies any shortness of breath.

For his hypertension, the patient states that his blood pressure has been around 125/72 recently. He is still taking 2.5 mg of Norvasc.

Regarding his type 2 diabetes, his last hemoglobin A1c was 7.2. He takes metformin 500 mg. The patient states that he does not check his blood glucose levels regularly.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports that he currently takes metformin 500 mg and Norvasc 2.5 mg.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports left elbow, arm, and neck pain.

VITALS

The patient's blood pressure today is 150/90.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Slight murmur detected, not heard before.

ASSESSMENT

Left arm pain.
Type 2 diabetes.
Hypertension.

PLAN

Regarding his left arm pain, I have explained to him that his symptoms are likely a mild heart attack. I have recommended that we obtain an EKG for further evaluation. I have also recommended that the patient take aspirin and nitroglycerin for pain. The patient will follow up with me once the EKG results are available for review and further discussion.

In regards to his diabetes, the patient will continue the 500 mg of metformin for now.

For his hypertension, the patient will continue the 2.5 mg of Norvasc.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abdominal pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of chronic migraines and hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports enjoyment in traveling and notes that she has not had any big trips since visiting Europe last summer.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports use of Excedrin Migraine when needed and occasionally sumatriptan. She also takes lisinopril 20 mg per day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue, chills, and decreased appetite. Denies fever.
Gastrointestinal: Reports abdominal pain, nausea, and heartburn. Denies vomiting, diarrhea, and hematochezia.
Genitourinary: Denies dysuria and hematuria.

VITALS

Blood pressure is slightly elevated.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Cardiovascular

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from prior exam.
Gastrointestinal

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: Soft, no masses. Mild to moderate tenderness to palpation in right upper quadrant. Equivocal Murphy's sign in right upper quadrant. Nontender right lower quadrant with deep palpation. No CVA tenderness.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Abdominal pain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with acute abdominal pain with right upper quadrant tenderness concerning for cholelithiasis or cholecystitis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Patient was advised to remain NPO pending her results in case surgery is needed.
- Medical treatment: CBC, chem 12, urinalysis, HCG qualitative, and right upper quadrant ultrasound were all ordered and will be performed today.

2. Migraine headaches.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of chronic migraines with occasional bouts of migraines, but no recent issues.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Patient counseled on avoidance of alcohol binges and caffeine binges. We also discussed trying to get enough sleep.
- Medical Treatment: She will continue to use Excedrin as needed. Refill for sumatriptan was provided today which she can take as needed for breakthrough migraine pain.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has been monitoring her blood pressure at home which has been under adequate control. Her blood pressure was only slightly elevated today in office.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Patient encouraged to continue with her daily blood pressure monitoring.
- Medical Treatment: Refill for lisinopril 20 mg per day was provided today.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

We will follow up with the patient regarding her results today. If she is cleared to return home, we will see her back for follow-up in 4 weeks.

4.  **Follow-up:** Will follow up on today's test results before patient leaves. If patient is cleared to go home today, schedule follow-up appointment in approximately 4 weeks.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of seasonal allergies, diabetes type 2, and hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking metformin 500 mg as well as hydrochlorothiazide every day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies any fever or body aches.
HENT: Reports sore throat and nasal congestion.
Respiratory: Reports productive cough with green phlegm. Denies any shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: Elevated at 144/72 mm Hg. The remainder of the vital signs look good.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No frontal sinus tenderness. Bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Mouth:
- Examination of Throat: Erythema of the pharynx. Tonsils are symmetrical. No exudates.

Neck
- General Examination: Anterior cervical adenopathy.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No edema.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Cough.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with symptoms similar to an upper respiratory infection. Most likely it is a virus that is causing her symptoms, especially as she reports being around some else with similar symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained that we often let the virus run its course while we treat her symptoms. I advised her to be cautious with over-the-counter cough medicines as certain ones can affect her blood pressure and diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: She increase her fluid intake. I recommended she try Coricidin HBP as a safer alternative to her cough medicine. The patient should rest frequently. I will order a COVID-19 test.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Stable with medication.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue with dietary restrictions.
- Medical Treatment: We will continue her on her metformin 500 mg twice a day. Repeat hemoglobin A1c will be due at her next visit.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Her blood pressure is elevated today, and it sounds like it has been trending higher at home as well.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue limiting her intake of salty foods. >I recommend that she take her hydrochlorothiazide in the morning because it can result in more frequent urination.
- Medical Treatment: We will increase her dose of hydrochlorothiazide to 25 mg once a day. She will continue checking her blood pressure a few times a week at different times of the day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
augmented note:
S:
**Chief Complaint:** Hacking cough for about three days.

**History of Present Illness:** Hannah is a patient presenting with a hacking cough that started three days ago. The cough was initially gradual but has become productive with green phlegm. She reports associated symptoms of a sore throat and nasal congestion. She denies fever, shortness of breath, body aches, nausea, or vomiting. She reports being around her sister, who was sick with similar symptoms, just prior to the onset of her own symptoms. She has been drinking lots of water and taking over-the-counter cough medication, which she feels is not helping. She was on vacation last week and felt well, with symptoms starting after her return.

**Past Medical History:**
*   Seasonal allergies (spring, with sneezing and runny nose)
*   Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
*   Hypertension

**Past Surgical History:** None mentioned.

**Family History:** Sister recently sick with similar symptoms. Other family members are doing well.

**Social History:** Reports being busy with life and work. Was on vacation last week. No smoking or alcohol use mentioned.

**Medications:**
*   Metformin 500 mg (Patient reports taking it okay)
*   Hydrochlorothiazide (Patient reports taking it everyday)
*   Over-the-counter cough medication (Name/dose/frequency not specified, patient reports it is not working)

**Allergies:** Seasonal allergies (sneezing, runny nose in spring). No drug or food allergies mentioned.

**Review of Systems:**
*   **General:** Denies fever, denies body aches.
*   **HEENT:** Reports sore throat, nasal congestion.
*   **Respiratory:** Reports hacking cough, productive with green phlegm. Denies shortness of breath.
*   **Gastrointestinal:** Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.

O:
**Vitals:**
*   Blood Pressure: 144/72 mmHg (elevated)
*   Other vitals noted as overall good, specific values not provided in transcript.

**Physical Exam:**
*   **Head/Sinuses:** No frontal sinus tenderness. Bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness noted.
*   **Mouth/Throat:** Pharynx with erythema. Tonsils symmetrical, no exudates appreciated.
*   **Neck:** Anterior cervical adenopathy appreciated.
*   **Cardiovascular:** Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
*   **Respiratory:** Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi appreciated.
*   **Extremities:** No edema appreciated in lower extremities.

**Labs/Imaging:**
*   COVID-19 test ordered today (results pending).

A:
1.  **Upper Respiratory Infection (URI), likely viral:** Patient presents with acute onset of cough, productive green phlegm, sore throat, and nasal congestion following exposure to a sick contact with similar symptoms. Physical exam reveals pharyngeal erythema, anterior cervical adenopathy, and bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness. Pertinent negatives include absence of fever, shortness of breath, and clear lungs on exam, making viral etiology most likely and ruling out pneumonia at this time. COVID-19 remains a possibility given the current pandemic context and will be tested for.
2.  **Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus:** Stable on current medication (Metformin 500mg). Patient reports blood sugars running around 120 range and tolerating Metformin well without side effects like diarrhea. Hemoglobin A1c is due at the next visit.
3.  **Hypertension:** Blood pressure is elevated today at 144/72 mmHg and patient reports elevated readings at home (around 140s systolic). Patient is currently on a low dose of Hydrochlorothiazide and reports taking it daily. Diet review indicates difficulty with sugar intake but attempts to limit salty foods.

P:
1.  **Upper Respiratory Infection (URI), likely viral:**
    *   **Supportive Care:** Encourage increased fluid intake and rest.
    *   **Symptom Management:** Continue supportive care. Recommend trying Coricidin HBP for cough/cold symptoms, advising caution due to potential effects on blood pressure and diabetes. Discontinue current OTC cough medicine as it is not effective.
    *   **Testing:** COVID-19 test ordered today. Results will be provided.
    *   **Education:** Discuss the likely viral nature of the infection and the importance of letting the virus run its course with supportive care. Explain rationale for not prescribing antibiotics at this time.
2.  **Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus:**
    *   **Medication:** Continue Metformin 500mg (daily or twice daily as previously prescribed).
    *   **Monitoring:** Repeat Hemoglobin A1c at the next scheduled visit (~every 3 months). Encourage continued home blood sugar monitoring.
    *   **Education:** Discuss the role of diet, particularly limiting sugar intake, in managing diabetes. Explain the purpose of the Hgb A1c test.
3.  **Hypertension:**
    *   **Medication:** Increase Hydrochlorothiazide dose to 25mg once daily.
    *   **Monitoring:** Continue home blood pressure monitoring a few times per week at different times of the day.
    *   **Education:** Advise taking Hydrochlorothiazide in the morning due to potential diuretic effect. Encourage continued efforts to limit salty foods in the diet.

**Follow-up:** Follow-up plan for URI depends on COVID test results. Hgb A1c to be checked at next scheduled visit. Continue monitoring BP at home. Return precautions not explicitly discussed in transcript.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Rogers is a pleasant 50-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain.

For the past few weeks, the patient has been experiencing constant pain isolated to the left shoulder. She denies any known injury or trauma; however, she is very active and is currently renovating her basement. She denies any associated numbness or tingling as well. While movements such as reaching and lifting exacerbate her pain, full flexion of the shoulder is the most severe. Her pain is also exacerbated if she lays on her shoulder, which subsequently causes sleep disturbance due to her being uncomfortable. She typically takes Tylenol Extra Strength, 2 tablets every 6 to 8 hours, for aches and pains associated with her active lifestyle, and doing so reduces her shoulder pain to 2-3/10 on the pain scale. Without medication, she rates her pain as 7/10.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient denies any previous trauma or injury to left shoulder.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that she has a very active lifestyle. She has also been renovating her basement recently.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that she has been taking Tylenol Extra Strength, 2 tablets every 6 to 8 hours.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies left shoulder numbness or tingling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is brisk at less than 3 seconds.
NEURO: Motor and sensation in the left shoulder are intact to light touch.
MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grip bilaterally.

RESULTS

X-ray imaging of the left shoulder was performed and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I believe this is most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. We discussed the nature of this condition in detail, and I have ordered an MRI for further evaluation. I'm going to put in a referral for 6 to 8 weeks of physical therapy, during which time she should continue with Tylenol as-needed. If her symptoms do not improve, we can consider administering a steroid injection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 2 weeks.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Matthew Allen is a pleasant 40-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain. The onset of his pain began yesterday after he went up for a rebound while playing basketball and felt a pop in his knee. He states that he experienced swelling and difficulty with ambulation following this incident. He locates his pain today to the medial aspect of his knee. His pain is described as aching and is rated at 4 out of 10. In terms of his swelling, he states that this has improved some. He is also able to weight-bear, but he finds that he is favoring his left leg while doing so. His tried treatments include Tylenol with some relief as well as rest.

The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes. He reports that he does not check is blood pressure at home very often, but he typically runs 140 to 150 range over 80. He is taking 5 mg of Norvasc daily. In terms of his diet, he states that he enjoys eating whatever he likes. His most recent A1C was 7.2. He is taking metformin 500 mg daily, however there are days where he skips this because of gastrointestinal upset. He denies checking his blood sugar at home consistently and that when he does check he has been around 150.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports playing basketball, however this most recent event was the first time he played in 2 years.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports he is taking Norvasc 5 mg daily, metformin 500 mg daily, and Tylenol.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure is 140/80 today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory effort no respiratory distress
MSK: Examination of the right knee: Pain with palpation over the medial aspect. Mild pain with flexion and extension. Edema, swelling, and ecchymosis noted. Mild redness. Negative varus and valgus stress test with firm endpoint.

RESULTS

4 views of the right knee were taken. These reveal no evidence of any fractures or dislocations. No other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Right knee MCL strain.
Diabetes.
Hypertension.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the right knee to further evaluate for a possible MCL tear. In the meantime, he will continue with Tylenol for pain relief. I have also prescribed him meloxicam 15 mg for pain and swelling. He will be placed into a knee immobilizer and has been advised to remain non weight-bearing for the next couple of weeks.

In terms of his diabetes, he was advised to start logging his blood sugars daily and to avoid eating large amounts of strawberries. He will also be provided with a referral for a consult with a nutritionist.

For his hypertension, we are going to increase his Norvasc to 5 mg daily as his blood pressures have been elevated. We discussed our goal is for him to get closer to the 120/80 range.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review his MRI results.

**Chief Complaint:** Right knee pain, follow-up for hypertension and diabetes.

**History of Present Illness:** Mr. Matthew Allen presents today for evaluation of right knee pain. The pain began yesterday while playing basketball when he went up for a rebound and felt a "pop" in his knee upon landing. Immediately following the injury, he experienced swelling and significant difficulty walking. He describes the pain as "real achy" and locates it to the "inside" (medial aspect) of his right knee. Swelling has decreased "some" since yesterday. He is now able to bear weight but is favoring the leg. Pain is currently rated as 4/10. He attempted Tylenol yesterday with "a little" relief. Rest has helped more than anything.

He also presents for follow-up of his chronic conditions.
**Hypertension:** Takes Norvasc 5 mg daily and reports compliance. He does not check blood pressure at home often. When he does, readings are typically in the 140-150s systolic over 80 diastolic. He reports eating "anything I want."
**Diabetes Mellitus:** Most recent A1C was 7.2. Takes Metformin 500 mg daily but skips doses sometimes due to stomach upset. He does not check blood sugar at home consistently. When he does check, readings are around 150. He reports eating "anything I want."

**Medical History:**
Hypertension
Diabetes Mellitus

**Surgical History:** Not discussed.

**Family History:** Not discussed.

**Social History:** Reports playing basketball yesterday for the first time in two years. Reports eating "anything I want." Smoking/Alcohol not discussed.

**Medications:**
Norvasc 5 mg daily
Metformin 500 mg daily
Tylenol PRN (for knee pain)

**Allergies:** Not discussed.

**Review of Systems:**
General: Denies fever, chills, weight changes.
HEENT: Denies headache, vision changes, sore throat.
Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath, wheezing.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, edema (other than knee).
Gastrointestinal: Reports stomach upset with Metformin. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (other than medication side effect).
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling. Denies other joint pain or swelling.
Endocrine: Reports history of diabetes. Denies polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia (other than related to known diabetes).

O:
**Vitals:**
BP: 140/80 (today in clinic)

**Physical Exam:**
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally (stated "lungs sound good").
Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur noted.
Right Knee:
Inspection: Edema, ecchymosis, mild redness noted.
Palpation: Pain to palpation over the medial aspect of the knee.
Range of Motion: Mild pain with flexion and extension.
Ligamentous Testing: Negative varus and valgus stress tests with firm endpoint.

**Results:**
Right Knee X-ray (4 views): Normal. No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

A:
1.  **Right Knee Pain, likely MCL Strain:** Acute onset pain following basketball injury with reported pop, swelling, and difficulty ambulating. Exam reveals medial joint line tenderness, edema, ecchymosis, and mild redness. Ligamentous testing (varus/valgus) is negative with a firm endpoint, making a complete tear less likely but not ruling it out. X-ray is negative for fracture or bony abnormality. This presentation is consistent with a medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain. MRI is needed to definitively rule out a higher-grade tear or other soft tissue injury.
2.  **Hypertension, Suboptimally Controlled:** Patient reports compliance with Norvasc 5 mg daily, but home blood pressure readings are elevated (140-150s/80s), and clinic BP today is 140/80, above goal of 120/80. Diet is poor.
3.  **Diabetes Mellitus Type 2, Suboptimally Controlled:** A1C 7.2 indicates poor glycemic control. Patient reports non-adherence to Metformin 500 mg daily due to GI upset and infrequent home blood sugar monitoring (readings around 150 when checked). Diet is poor.

P:
1.  **Right Knee Pain/MCL Strain:**
    *   Order MRI of the right knee to evaluate for MCL tear and other soft tissue injuries.
    *   Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling.
    *   Continue Tylenol PRN for pain.
    *   Apply knee immobilizer.
    *   Advise non-weight bearing on the right leg for the next couple of weeks.
2.  **Hypertension:**
    *   Discussed increasing Norvasc dose given elevated blood pressures (specific new dose not clearly articulated in transcript).
    *   Reinforce goal blood pressure of 120/80.
    *   Counsel on dietary modification for blood pressure control.
3.  **Diabetes Mellitus:**
    *   Advise daily home blood sugar monitoring and keeping a log book to track readings.
    *   Provide referral for Nutrition Consult to improve diet.
    *   Discussed Metformin non-adherence due to GI upset and possibility of alternative medication if needed (plan focused on monitoring and nutrition consult for now).
    *   Advised patient to avoid high-sugar foods like strawberries due to diabetes.

**Follow-up:** Return to clinic in 2 weeks to review MRI results and discuss management of chronic conditions.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Elevated and fluctuating blood pressures.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports he enjoys playing golf.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports he is taking lisinopril 20 mg twice per day, atorvastatin, and occasional Tylenol.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Reports heaviness in chest. Denies heart palpitations or syncope.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Neurological: Reports headache and lightheadedness. Denies syncope.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Mild bibasilar rales, but no wheezes or rhonchi. Excellent air movement.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from prior.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Elevated blood pressure.
- Medical Reasoning: I do think his blood pressure is uncontrolled and we need to make some adjustments to his medication.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The patient and I discussed that he should stay well hydrated during warm weather. I explained he loses more fluid when perspiring and will need to increase his fluid intake as needed. We discussed that drinking 6 to 8 standard glasses of water per day is an adequate amount. He may want to increase that amount if he is feeling particularly dehydrated or as he increases his activity level. I cautioned him from drinking more than 2 alcoholic beverages a week.
- Medical Treatment: I am going to increase his lisinopril to 60 mg twice per day. Prescription for 25 mg per day of hydrochlorothiazide provided as well. He will check his blood pressure twice a day for the next 2 weeks.

2. Hyperlipidemia.
- Medical Reasoning: Stable.
- Medical Treatment: I will order a cholesterol panel, CBC with differential, and comprehensive metabolic panel. We will also obtain an urinalysis to assess his kidney function as well. He will continue the current management with his atorvastatin.

This is likely exacerbated by reported medication non-adherence, particularly on weekends. Poorly controlled hypertension is the suspected etiology for her current headaches. Sinusitis and lymphadenopathy were considered and ruled out on limited exam.
2.  **Headache, likely secondary to hypertension:** Patient reports new onset, worsening headaches described as pounding, partially relieved by Tylenol. Given the concurrent significant elevation in blood pressure, the headaches are assessed as likely secondary to hypertension. Other causes such as typical migraines or sinus issues were considered and deemed less likely based on patient report and limited exam.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he has a frequent history of strep throat with 4 episodes within the last 5 months.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he is a student. He also mentions that he rides his bike every so often and that he is in the process of switching jobs. His new job will be at a restaurant.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports that his siblings are mostly healthy. He does have a brother who smokes while at home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fatigue or change in appetite.
Genitourinary: Reports increased urine output.
Musculoskeletal: Reports left-side back pain.
Endocrine: Reports increased water consumption

PHYSICAL EXAM

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Mouth: Normal.
- Examination of Throat: Pharynx without erythema, swelling, or exudate. Tonsils are midline.

Neck
- General Examination: Neck is supple without lymphadenopathy. No cervical adenopathy.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No tenderness. No rebound or guarding.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No back tenderness with palpation.

Hematology/Lymphatic/Immunology
- Palpation: No enlarged lymph nodes.

RESULTS

Previous CT scan is reviewed and demonstrates evidence of swelling potentially related to glomerulonephritis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Glomerulonephritis.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with a complaint of back pain, although this was not present on exam today with palpation. He also has a history of recurrent strep throat and a recent CT scan with concerns of possible glomerulonephritis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The patient was recommended to watch his salt intake.
- Medical Treatment: We will refer him to an ENT for further evaluation and treatment. We will also order a lipid panel, UA, CMP, CBC, vitamin D, and a TSH. A work note was provided today as well.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

He will follow up in 1 week via telehealth, however if the results are abnormal this will need to be an in-person visit.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he is a teacher.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking lisinopril 20 mg daily and metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports "feeling warm". Denies chills.
HENT: Reports nasal congestion, sore throat, and sinus pressure.
Respiratory: Reports productive cough with yellow sputum. Denies dyspnea.
Musculoskeletal: Reports body aches and right knee pain. Denies right knee instability.

VITALS

Temperature is 98.4 today.
BP: 125/62.
Heart rate is nice and slow in the 80s.
SpO2 is 97% on room air.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: Pain to palpation to the bilateral maxillary sinuses.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Nose: Erythema and edema of the nasal turbinates bilaterally with associated yellow discharge.
- Examination of Throat: Uvula is midline. Pharynx without erythema, swelling, or exudate in the peritonsillar space.

Neck
- General Examination: Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy noted.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Coarse rhonchi present bilaterally that clears with cough.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No masses or tenderness.
- Auscultation: Bowel sounds normal in all 4 quadrants.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right knee: Pain to palpation. Decreased flexion and extension. Ecchymosis present medially. No evidence of an effusion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Cough.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a cough likely due to a viral syndrome such as mild bronchitis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that antibiotics are not needed at this time, however, if his symptoms worsen we will consider a chest x-ray. - Medical Treatment: Continue over-the-counter medications. I will prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice a day.

2. Right knee pain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's physical exam is consistent with a right medial lateral ligament strain.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed physical therapy will be beneficial for strengthening the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescription for meloxicam 15 mg once a day provided. Referral to physical therapy provided. Right knee x-ray ordered.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure in office today looked great and appears stable at this time.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. I will order a lipid panel.

4. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient does not check his blood sugar at home and admits to not watching his diet.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of diet as there can be complications with diabetes such as kidney dysfunction and eye problems that we want to avoid. He was also advised of the importance of blood sugar monitoring.
- Medical Treatment: Hemoglobin A1c ordered. Continue metformin as prescribed. Start blood sugar monitoring and report levels through patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

We will contact the patient with his lab results when ready.
augmented note:
S:
**Chief Complaint:** Cough. Patient also reports right knee pain after a fall.

**History of Present Illness:** 74-year-old male presents with a cough that started approximately one week ago. Initially non-productive, it has become productive with yellow sputum over the past two days, during which time he reports feeling worse. He reports associated nasal congestion, drainage down his throat, and sinus pressure. He denies fevers (though feels warm), chills, and shortness of breath. He reports generalized body aches at times. He has been taking over-the-counter cough and cold medication (Dayquil), which has provided slight relief.

Today, while coughing, he fell down approximately four to five stairs, injuring his right knee. He reports immediate pain in the right knee, primarily on the inside (medial aspect). He is able to walk but reports a slight limp. He can bend and straighten the knee and denies instability or feeling like it will give out. He has not taken any medication specifically for the knee pain.

**Past Medical History:** Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus.

**Social History:** Works as a teacher. Reports not checking blood pressure or blood sugars at home and not watching salt or sugar intake. Lives with wife.

**Medications:**
Lisinopril 20 mg daily (patient reports taking a white pill, dose confirmed by doctor)
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily (patient reports taking a big pill twice daily, dose/frequency confirmed by doctor)
Dayquil (OTC, for cough/cold)

**Allergies:** None mentioned.

**Review of Systems:**
Constitutional: Reports feeling warm, reports body aches. Denies fevers, denies chills.
HEENT: Reports nasal congestion, drainage down throat, sinus pressure. Denies sore throat.
Respiratory: Reports cough productive of yellow sputum. Denies shortness of breath.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations.
Musculoskeletal: Reports body aches, reports right knee pain. Denies right knee instability.

O:
**Vital Signs:**
Temperature: 98.4 °F
Blood Pressure: 125/62 mmHg
Heart Rate: 80s bpm, regular
Oxygen Saturation: 97% on room air

**Physical Exam:**
Head and Face: Pain to palpation of the bilateral maxillary sinuses.
Nose: Erythema and edema of the nasal turbinates bilaterally with associated yellow discharge.
Throat: Uvula midline, no erythema, edema, or exudate in the peritonsillar space.
Neck: Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy appreciated.
Lungs: Coarse rhonchi present bilaterally, clears with cough.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur appreciated.
Right Knee: Pain to palpation. Decreased flexion and extension. Associated ecchymosis to the medial aspect. No evidence of an effusion.

A:
1.  **Viral Syndrome/Mild Bronchitis:** Patient presents with a productive cough, nasal congestion, sinus pressure, and constitutional symptoms consistent with an upper respiratory infection. Objective findings of bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness, nasal congestion/discharge, cervical lymphadenopathy, and bilateral coarse rhonchi that clear with cough support a diagnosis of viral syndrome likely involving mild bronchitis. Pneumonia is considered in the differential given the productive cough and rhonchi, but denied symptoms of fever, chills, and shortness of breath, along with rhonchi clearing with cough, make it less likely at this time.
2.  **Right Medial Collateral Ligament Strain:** Patient reports twisting his right knee during a fall down stairs today. Subjective report of medial knee pain and objective findings of pain to palpation over the right knee, decreased range of motion (flexion/extension), and medial ecchymosis are consistent with a ligamentous injury, specifically a medial collateral ligament strain. No effusion or reported instability decreases concern for more severe internal derangement. Fracture is considered given the fall mechanism.
3.  **Hypertension:** Patient has a history of hypertension. Blood pressure is well-controlled in the office today (125/62). Patient reports not monitoring blood pressure at home or watching salt intake, but reports taking prescribed lisinopril.
4.  **Diabetes Mellitus:** Patient has a history of diabetes. Patient reports not monitoring blood sugars at home and not watching sugar intake, but reports taking prescribed metformin. No objective data regarding glycemic control available from the transcript.

P:
1.  **Viral Syndrome/Mild Bronchitis:**
    *   Continue supportive care and over-the-counter medications as needed.
    *   Prescribe Guaifenesin 600 mg twice daily to help with phlegm expectoration.
    *   Patient education provided: Antibiotics are not indicated for a viral infection at this time.
    *   Return precautions: Patient instructed to call if symptoms worsen (e.g., increased fever, shortness of breath, worsening cough), at which point a chest x-ray will be considered to rule out pneumonia.
2.  **Right Medial Collateral Ligament Strain:**
    *   Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg once daily for pain and inflammation.
    *   Referral to physical therapy to help strengthen muscles around the knee.
    *   Order Right Knee X-ray to rule out fracture given the fall mechanism.
3.  **Hypertension:**
    *   Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
    *   Order Lipid Panel.
    *   Patient education provided regarding the importance of home blood pressure monitoring and dietary modifications (implied by discussion).
4.  **Diabetes Mellitus:**
    *   Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
    *   Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess glycemic control.
    *   Patient education provided regarding the importance of monitoring blood sugars and dietary modifications to prevent long-term complications (kidney dysfunction, eye problems).
    *   Plan for patient to begin monitoring blood sugars and report levels via the patient portal.

**Follow-up:** Patient will be contacted with results of ordered labs and imaging.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Headache and high blood pressure.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Neurological: Reports blurry vision, dizziness, and headaches.

VITALS

Blood pressure today was 172/98. Oxygenation is within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention. No carotid bruits.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from last year.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Slight edema to bilateral upper extremities. 1+ pitting edema noted in the bilateral lower extremities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Hypertension, uncontrolled.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is is elevated.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that this could be multifactorial; for example, her diet, her medications regimen, or the medication she is currently on could be a factor in her elevated blood pressure. I encouraged the patient to take her current medication regimen today. I encouraged her to monitor her blood pressure 3 times a week. We also discussed the patient speaking to our nutritionist to help her diet. I recommended a DASH diet.
- Medical Treatment: She will continue her current medication regimen.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's diabetes is uncontrolled.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to continue taking her blood sugars to make sure that the change in medication is effective.
- Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1500 mg.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 4 weeks.

Associated symptoms include occasional dizziness and blurry vision. She denies chest pain and shortness of breath. *   Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

Contributing factors likely include poor medication adherence (chlorthalidone taken every other day) and high-sodium diet. Murmur noted but unchanged from prior year.
2.  **Uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus:** Based on today's elevated fasting blood sugar (170 mg/dL) and patient-reported poor medication adherence (metformin taken every other day). Recent consumption of Easter candy may be a contributing factor.

P:
1.  **Uncontrolled Hypertension:**
    *   **Medication:** Continue Chlorthalidone. Strongly encouraged daily adherence; suggested setting a reminder (e.g., on phone).
    *   **Monitoring:** Recommend obtaining a home blood pressure monitor. Instructed patient to monitor blood pressure three times per week.

    *   **Medication:** Increase Metformin dose to 1500 mg (frequency not specified, but presumably daily based on standard practice and discussion of adherence).
    *   **Monitoring:** Continue home blood sugar monitoring as usual to assess effectiveness of medication change.
    *   **Follow-up:** Re-evaluate blood sugar control at the 1-month follow-up appointment.

**Follow-up:** Patient to follow up in 4 weeks (1 month).

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Steven Reed is a pleasant 60-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of back pain. The onset of his pain began 2 years ago after he fell and landed onto his back while playing basketball. His pain is rated at 7 out of 10 and is described a sharp with occasional throbbing. At times his pain will radiate down his left lower extremity. He also reports experiencing intermittent numbness in his toes. Prolonged standing exacerbates his pain and makes him feel weak. He is able to get some pain relief when laying on his side. In terms of his bowel and bladder habits, he reports 1 episode of incontinence over the last 2 years which he believes was due to prolonged standing and possible alcohol consumption. He other denies any other changes and denies loss of sensation in the genital or rectal area. He has tried an injection in the past, but notes that he does not like needles and had to be held down. Pain medication was tried but he is unable to recall the name of the medication. He also attended physical therapy with minimal relief. Currently he states that he is not very active and tends to watch tv all day. He has gained 80 lbs over the last year.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports previously playing basketball, but he is now not very active and sits at home all day. He has a history of smoking, but denies smoking currently.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports his 4th cousin has scoliosis.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Genitourinary: Denies bowel or bladder changes.
Musculoskeletal: Reports back pain.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation is in 95 percentile range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No Murmur.
NEURO: Decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at the L4 dermatome. Patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
MSK: Examination of the lumbar spine: No overlying erythema or ecchymosis. Midline tenderness along the L4-5 disc space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion and extension. Positive supine straight leg raise.

RESULTS

The MRI of the lumbar spine was reviewed. This shows evidence of disc desiccation and a disc bulge with a paracentral disc herniation resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis.

ASSESSMENT

Chronic lumbar back pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and MRI findings today, I explained to the patient that he has a herniated disc at L4-5 with radiculopathy. We discussed the nature of the diagnosis as well as treatment options. I have recommended that we start with a spinal corticosteroid injection under fluoroscopy. The nature of the procedure was discussed. A prescription was given today to help with his anxiety during the injection as he states he does not tolerate needles. We also had a long discussion regarding pain medication. I advised him that we can do up to 4 injections per year and that we need to hold off on proceeding with pain medication until we assess his progress. I also explained to him that pain medication is not a long term solution and that if he remains symptomatic, it is possible surgery would be recommended.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will return for follow-up after to assess his progress after his spinal injection.
augmented note:
S:
**Chief Complaint:** Back pain.

**History of Present Illness:** Mr. Steven presents for evaluation of chronic back pain. The pain began approximately 2 years ago after he fell and landed on his back while playing basketball. He rates his pain as a 7 out of 10. He describes the pain as sharp with occasional throbbing. The pain sometimes radiates down his left leg, and he experiences intermittent numbness in his toes. Prolonged standing aggravates his pain and causes weakness. Lying on his side provides some relief. He reports one episode of bowel incontinence over the last 2 years, which he attributes to prolonged standing and possible alcohol consumption; he denies consistent bowel or bladder incontinence and denies loss of sensation in the genital or rectal area. He has previously tried an injection (type unknown) and physical therapy, which provided minimal relief. He also tried pain medication ("white pill") which he states was effective. He reports a sedentary lifestyle, sitting at home and watching TV all day, and has gained approximately 80 pounds in the past year.

**Past Medical History:** History of back pain, previous spinal injection (type unknown), previous physical therapy, previous pain medication trial (type unknown).

**Past Surgical History:** Not specified.

**Family History:** Reports 4th cousin has scoliosis; denies direct family history of spine conditions (sister, brother, mother, father).

**Social History:** Sedentary lifestyle, previously played basketball, watches TV all day. History of smoking (denies current smoking). Reports significant weight gain (80 lbs in past year).

**Review of Systems:**
*   **General:** Reports significant weight gain (80 lbs in past year), sedentary lifestyle.
*   **Musculoskeletal:** Reports chronic back pain radiating down the left leg, associated toe numbness, weakness with prolonged standing.
*   **Genitourinary:** Reports one episode of bowel incontinence in the past 2 years; denies consistent incontinence.

**Medications:** Not specified by name or dose in transcript.
**Allergies:** No known allergies specified in transcript.

O:
**Vitals:** Oxygen saturation in the 95th percentile range. (Other vitals not specified in transcript).

**Physical Exam:**
*   **Cardiovascular:** Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur appreciated.
*   **Musculoskeletal (Lumbar Spine):** No overlying erythema or ecchymosis. Midline tenderness noted on palpation at the L4-5 disc space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion and extension. Supine straight leg raise test is positive.
*   **Neurological:** Decreased sensation to light touch noted at the right lateral thigh at the L4 dermatome. Patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.

**Labs/Imaging:**
*   **Lumbar Spine MRI:** Reviewed. Results show disc desiccation, a disc bulge with paracentral disc herniation resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis at L4-5.

A:
**Problem List:**
1.  Chronic Lumbar Back Pain with Radiculopathy

**Assessment:**
Mr. Steven presents with chronic, severe (7/10) lumbar back pain radiating down the left leg with associated toe numbness and weakness, exacerbated by standing and improved by lying on his side. Physical exam reveals midline and right paravertebral tenderness at L4-5, pain with lumbar range of motion, a positive straight leg raise, and decreased sensation in the right L4 dermatome. Review of his lumbar MRI confirms disc desiccation and a disc bulge with paracentral herniation causing moderate right neural foraminal stenosis at L4-5. These findings are consistent with a herniated disc at L4-5 causing radiculopathy, which explains his reported symptoms and objective findings. His significant weight gain and sedentary lifestyle are contributing factors. The single episode of incontinence is noted but not felt to be indicative of cauda equina syndrome given the lack of consistent symptoms or saddle anesthesia.

P:
**Chronic Lumbar Back Pain with Radiculopathy:**
*   **Intervention:** Recommend spinal corticosteroid injection under fluoroscopy at the L4-5 level to target inflammation and the disc bulge.
*   **Medication:** Prescribe an anxiety medication to be taken prior to the injection appointment to address patient's stated anxiety regarding needles.
*   **Patient Education:** Discussed the diagnosis of a herniated disc pinching the nerve at L4-5 as the cause of his symptoms. Explained the rationale for the injection as the initial treatment step. Discussed the procedure, noting it is quick and common, performed under X-ray guidance (fluoroscopy), and typically takes about an hour. Explained that injections can be repeated up to 4 times per year if successful. Discussed the plan to assess the effectiveness of the injection before considering chronic pain medication, explaining that pain medication is not ideal for long-term management. Advised that if symptoms persist despite injection therapy, surgical options may need to be considered in the future.
*   **Follow-up:** Patient instructed to schedule the spinal injection appointment at the front desk. Return for follow-up appointment after the injection to assess symptom improvement and further management planning.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Wright is a pleasant 36-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right shoulder pain. The onset of her pain began 3 weeks ago, when she was painting on a ladder when she reached out to catch herself because she fell. She states that she braced herself with her right arm. The patient reports that she was able to get up and continue painting. She states that she experienced numbness and tingling in her arm and hand when she initially injured her right shoulder, however this has resolved. She states that she iced her arm and took Advil for pain. The patient denies any previous shoulder pain. She reports constant pain with lifting her arm overhead. The patient rates her pain level as a 6 out of 10 without medication and a 4 out of 10 with medication.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness and tingling.

VITALS

Vitals look good today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Brisk capillary refill of less than 3 seconds.
NEURO: Normal strength and sensation. Neurovascularly intact distally. Equal bilateral response to sensation and touch.
MSK: Examination of the right shoulder reveals limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness over the sternoclavicular joint. Good strong bilateral hand grips.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right shoulder taken today reveals no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the right shoulder. I referred her to formal physical therapy to strengthen her right shoulder. She will continue to take Advil as needed for pain.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks for re-evaluation.
augmented note:
S:
**Chief Complaint:** Right shoulder pain.

**History of Present Illness:** Patient presents with right shoulder pain that began approximately three weeks ago. The onset occurred while she was painting on a ladder, reaching out, when she fell and braced herself with her right arm. She reports being able to get up and continue painting despite the pain. Initially, she experienced numbness and tingling in the affected arm and hand, but this has since resolved. She has used ice and Advil for pain relief. She denies any previous pain in the right shoulder. The pain is described as constant with lifting her arm overhead, though some pain is intermittent. Without medication, she rates her pain as a 6 out of 10, which improves to a 4 out of 10 with medication.

**Past Medical History:** Not discussed.
**Past Surgical History:** Not discussed.
**Family History:** Not discussed.
**Social History:** Discussed home remodeling project. No other details regarding smoking, alcohol, or occupation mentioned.

**Review of Systems:**
*   **General:** Not discussed.
*   **HEENT:** Not discussed.
*   **Respiratory:** Not discussed.
*   **Cardiovascular:** Not discussed.
*   **Musculoskeletal:** Positive for right shoulder pain, pain with overhead lifting.
*   **Neurological:** Denies current numbness or tingling in the right arm/hand (initially present, now resolved).

**Medications:**
*   Advil (Ibuprofen) - Dose, route, frequency not specified, taken for pain.
No other medications discussed.

**Allergies:**
No allergies discussed.

O:
**Vitals:** Vitals look good. (Specific values not provided in transcript).

**Physical Exam:**
*   **Right Shoulder:** Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness to palpation over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness over the sternoclavicular joint.
*   **Extremities:** Good strong bilateral hand grips.
*   **Neurovascular (Right Arm):** Brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds). Equal and bilateral response to sensation and touch. Neurovascularly intact distally.

**Imaging:**
*   **Right Shoulder X-ray (today):** Reveals no fracture or bony abnormality.

A:
**Assessment:**
1.  **Right shoulder pain:** Most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. This is supported by the mechanism of injury (fall with bracing), location of pain and tenderness (greater tuberosity), limited range of motion, and improvement with NSAIDs. Acute bony injury has been ruled out by today's X-ray.

P:
**Plan:**
1.  **Right shoulder pain/Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy:**
    *   **Imaging:** Order MRI of the right shoulder to further evaluate soft tissue structures.
    *   **Physical Therapy:** Refer to formal physical therapy for 6-8 weeks to strengthen the shoulder and improve function. Patient educated on the expected success rate of PT.
    *   **Pain Management:** Continue NSAID therapy (Advil). Patient advised that Tylenol is also an option if tolerated.
    *   **Further Treatment:** Discussed potential for steroid injection in the future if symptoms persist or do not improve significantly with physical therapy.
    *   **Patient Education:** Explained that symptoms are likely due to injury to the rotator cuff tendons.
    *   **Follow-up:** Return to clinic in 2 weeks for re-evaluation of symptoms and response to initial treatment plan.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Vision changes in the right eye.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of high blood pressure.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports he is smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Eyes: Reports right eye vision changes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Eyes
- Examination of the right eye: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses present bilaterally. Right eye cornea is clear without NVI and cup-disc ratio is 0.2. Fundus of right eye shows retina is intact 360 degrees without holes or tears noted, and RPE changes in fovea. Posterior segment shows drusen of the macula, retinal thickening, and presence of subretinal fluid and exudate accumulation. Positive hemorrhage
Examination of the left eye: Cornea is clear. No NVI. Cup-disc ration is 0.3. RPE changes in fovea. No hemorrhage noted or subretinal fluid noted. Retina is attached appropriately.

RESULTS

OTC:
Drusen deposits under the RPE. SRF accumulation and choroidal neovascular membrane can also be visualized.

Fluorescein angiography:
Reveals that the focal area of the leakage in the right eye is consistent with neovascular age related macular degeneration.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Wet macular degeneration.
- Medical Reasoning: The diagnostic test and eye exams are consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration, also called wet macular degeneration.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained the nature of the diagnosis and that this is advanced to a stage that usually leads to more severe vision loss happening. We discussed this happens when those abnormal blood vessels start to grow beneath the retina leaking fluid and blood. Secondary to that, it creates a large blind spot in the center of his visual field. He was advised that this is the most common cause of severe vision loss. I explained the treatment plan at length. He understands he is going to be injected in the vitreous portion of the eye after we numb the eye, so he is not going to feel any pain. I advised injections given over time can slow the rate of the vision decline and maybe even stop it. However, I also have to let him know that there could be a situation where he may still note a small amount of vision loss, but this is his best chance of maintaining that vision for as long as he can. Additionally, patient was counseled on the importance of taking his blood pressure medication. Questions were invited and answered today.
- Medical Treatment: Lucentis injections once a month with his first being performed today.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

He also reports that straight lines, such as those in door frames or wall paneling, appear wavy or crooked when viewed with the right eye.

- Cardiovascular: History of hypertension. No other cardiovascular symptoms discussed.
- Respiratory: Reports smoking. No other respiratory symptoms discussed.

O:
**Vital Signs:** Not discussed.

**Physical Exam:**
- **Eyes:**
    - Anterior Segment: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses (IOLs) present bilaterally.
    - Right Eye: Cornea clear, no neovascularization of the iris (NVI). Peak hole cup-to-disc ratio 0.2.
    - Left Eye: Cornea clear, no NVI. Peak hole cup-to-disc ratio 0.3.
    - Fundus Examination:
        - Right Eye: Retina attached 360 degrees, no holes or tears noted. Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes in the fovea. Posterior segment shows drusen in the macula, retinal thickening, presence of subretinal fluid (SRF), exudate accumulation, and positive for hemorrhage.
        - Left Eye: RPE changes in the fovea. No hemorrhage noted or subretinal fluid noted. Retina attached appropriately.

**Diagnostic Results:**
- **Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):** Shows drusen deposits under the RPE, SRF accumulation, and choroidal neovascular membrane visualization.
- **Fluorescein Angiography:** Reveals a focal area of leakage in the right eye.

A:
**Assessment:**
1.  **Neovascular (Wet) Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD), Right Eye:** Based on subjective report of vision changes including decreased vision in dim light and metamorphopsia, coupled with objective findings on physical exam (drusen, retinal thickening, SRF, exudate, hemorrhage in macula) and diagnostic testing (OCT showing drusen, SRF, CNVM; Fluorescein Angiography showing leakage), consistent with neovascular AMD. This is noted to be an advanced stage commonly leading to severe vision loss due to abnormal blood vessel growth and leakage beneath the retina, causing a central blind spot.
2.  **Hypertension:** Patient reports history and current non-adherence with medication.
3.  **Tobacco Use:** Patient reports smoking one pack per day.

P:
**Plan:**
1.  **Neovascular (Wet) AMD, Right Eye:**
    - **Treatment:** Intravitreal injection of Lucentis (ranibizumab) into the right eye. First injection to be administered today.
    - **Frequency:** Monthly injections planned.
    - **Patient Education:** Discussed the diagnosis of wet AMD, its mechanism (abnormal vessels leaking fluid/blood), why it causes vision loss (central blind spot), and that it is a common cause of severe vision loss. Explained the treatment with Lucentis injections, including the procedure (injection into vitreous after numbing), expected sensation (no pain after numbing), and goals (slow/stop vision decline, best chance to maintain vision). Advised that some vision loss may still occur despite treatment. Patient verbalized understanding and agreement with the treatment plan.
2.  **Hypertension:**
    - **Counseling:** Strongly advised patient on the importance of taking blood pressure medication as prescribed daily.
    - **Strategy:** Recommended placing the pill bottle on the counter to aid in remembering to take the medication, starting today.
3.  **Tobacco Use:**
    - **Counseling:** Advised patient on the importance of cutting back or quitting smoking altogether due to its impact on overall health and potentially eye health.
4.  **Follow-up:** First Lucentis injection scheduled for today. Monthly injections planned thereafter. No specific follow-up appointment beyond injections discussed. Return precautions not explicitly discussed in transcript.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joe Reed is a pleasant 42-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right knee injury. The patient sustained this injury when he was skiing with some friends. He states the front end of his skis dug into the snow and he ended up doing a cartwheel through the air until he stopped halfway and felt a pop with immediate pain in his right knee. The patient reports pain and swelling in his right knee since the injury. He has been able to ambulate although he notes difficulty due to swelling and pain. The patient has been taking Advil as well as icing and applying heat to his knee intermittently. He denies any previous knee injuries.

The patient also reports right shoulder pain and bruising. He states he landed on his right shoulder when he fell. He reports tenderness with raising his arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling. Right shoulder pain and bruising.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 110/74 mmHg.
Heart Rate: 64 beats per minute.
Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths per minute.
Oxygen Saturation: 98%
Body Temperature: 97.9 degrees F.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Mild edema
MSK:
Examination of the right knee: Edema and ecchymosis surrounding the knee. Positive pain to palpation. Pain with flexion and extension. Full ROM.
Examination of the right shoulder: Mild bruising is present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and are reviewed today. No fracture is appreciated. No bony abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right knee contusion.
2. Right shoulder pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have advised him to rest his right knee and apply ice 2 to 3 times per day for 20 minutes at a time. He can take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. If his pain does not improve with the medication, he will return to the office and we will consider formal physical therapy.

With regards to his right shoulder, I have recommended that we obtain x-rays of the right shoulder as well.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me on an as-needed basis.
